notes.title: Treaty of Hudaybiyyah (628 CE): Strategy, Terms & Outcomes
notes.content: Seen initially as a 'loss', the 10-year truce enabled consolidation, outreach, and ultimately the peaceful Conquest of Makkah. Exams ask for clauses, political foresight, and Qur'anic framing (Fath).
keyTakeaways: Core terms: ceasefire, delayed 'Umrah next year, alliance framework, return clauses.
Strategic dividend: space for da'wah, tribal diplomacy, and coalition-building.
Model case for conflict de-escalation and international treaty law analogies.

resources.title: Research paper — Political Impacts of Hudaybiyyah (2024)

notes.title: Charter/Constitution of Madinah: Pluralism & Statecraft
notes.content: Foundational social contract defining rights/duties among Muslims and allied Jewish tribes; examined for clauses on security, dispute resolution, and ummah as a political community.
keyTakeaways: Clauses cover collective defense, blood-money norms, and religious autonomy.
Used to derive principles of citizenship and rule of law in early Islam.
Know scholarly debates on dating, textual layers, and transmission.

notes.title: Battle of Badr (624 CE): Turning Point
notes.content: Earliest decisive victory; questions emphasize causes, logistics, Qur'anic mention, and consequences for Meccan trade & Muslim morale.
keyTakeaways: Only battle named in the Qur'an; moral and political boost.
Know commanders, numbers (ranges), and immediate aftermath.
Use for comparing early vs later Madinan battles.

notes.title: Shūrā & Early Caliphal Selection
notes.content: Exam focus: Saqīfah, consultative precedent, and evolving mechanisms of leadership legitimation; compare ideals vs. later dynastic practice.
keyTakeaways: Shūrā as principle of mutual consultation; early boards/electors.
Saqīfah context and contestations; Abu Bakr's bay'ah.
Link to contemporary debates on Islamic governance.

notes.title: 'Umar ibn al-Khattāb: Administration & Welfare
notes.content: Frequently examined for judicial reforms, diwan/bayt al-māl organization, provincial oversight, and public welfare ethos.
keyTakeaways: Institution-building: administrative districts, accountability.
Justice & welfare: stipends, market oversight, rule of law.
Use as model for governance case studies.

resources.title: Britannica — Abu Bakr (context) & 'Umar in related entries
resources.description: Succession to 'Umar's reforms via linked pages

notes.title: Umayyads: Statecraft of ʿAbd al-Malik (r. 685–705)
notes.content: Arabicization of administration, coinage reform, consolidation, and monumental ideology (e.g., Dome of the Rock).
keyTakeaways: Standardized coinage & Arabic as chancery language.
Centralization after civil wars; provincial control.
Exam-favorite for comparing to Abbasid policies.

notes.title: Umayyads vs Abbasids: Comparative Governance
notes.content: Compare political bases (Arab tribal elites vs. Khurasani coalition), capitals (Damascus vs. Baghdad), policies, and cultural orientations.
keyTakeaways: Abbasid revolution (black banners), broader inclusivity of mawālī.
Shift in administrative culture; cosmopolitan Baghdad.
Use structured compare/contrast table in essays.

notes.title: House of Wisdom (Bayt al-Hikma): Translation & Knowledge
notes.content: Icon of Abbasid intellectual life; exams test functions (translation, research), patronage, and cross-civilizational transmission.
keyTakeaways: Greek, Persian, Indian works translated; new disciplines flourished.
Institutional learning (observatories, libraries) grew around it.
Note modern debates on exact institutional contours.

notes.title: Ibn Sīnā (Avicenna), al-Fārābī, Ibn Rushd: Philosophy & Science
notes.content: Know signature works (Canon of Medicine; political philosophy; commentaries on Aristotle) and influence on both Islamicate and European thought.
keyTakeaways: Avicenna: medical encyclopedism; metaphysics.
al-Fārābī: political philosophy; virtuous city.
Averroes: Aristotelian commentary, Latin reception.

notes.title: Sack of Baghdad (1258): End of Classical Abbasid Era
notes.content: Key turning point: Hulagu's siege, execution of al-Musta'sim, cultural devastation; frequently paired with causation and consequences for Islamic heartlands.
keyTakeaways: Date and actors; Il-Khanate formation in Iran.
Intellectual & demographic shock; shift of centers (e.g., Cairo).
Use primary/secondary synthesis; avoid inflated casualty claims.

notes.title: Conquest of Iberia (711) & Rise of al-Andalus
notes.content: Tāriq ibn Ziyād and Mūsā ibn Nuṣayr; exam ask for motives, rapid advance, administrative settlement, and cultural consequences.
keyTakeaways: From entry at Gibraltar to consolidation under Umayyads of Córdoba.
Early convivencia patterns and frontier dynamics.
Set up for Emirate/Caliphate of Córdoba themes.

notes.title: Córdoba & Granada: Architecture & Urban Culture
notes.content: Mosque–Cathedral of Córdoba and the Alhambra as case studies in Islamic art, politics of heritage, and aesthetics.
keyTakeaways: Know phases of expansion (Córdoba) and Nasrid program (Alhambra).
UNESCO status and heritage debates (contested memory).
Use architectural vocabulary (hypostyle, muqarnas, epigraphy).

resources.title: UNESCO Atlas — Historic Centre of Córdoba (site info)

notes.title: Taifas & Decline of Muslim Spain
notes.content: Fragmentation (Mulūk al-Ṭawā'if), Almoravids/Almohads, and Reconquista pressures; exams test chains of causation to 1492.
keyTakeaways: Taifa politics invited external intervention and Christian advances.
Military vs. fiscal strains; social fragmentation.
Anchor with dates, rulers, and key battles (e.g., Las Navas, 1212).

notes.title: Ottomans: Süleyman the Magnificent (r. 1520–66)
notes.content: Empire at zenith; legislation (Qānūn), military expansion, and imperial culture; common compare/contrast with earlier caliphates.
keyTakeaways: Kanuni's legal codification and administrative sophistication.
Balanced central authority with provincial governance.
Patronage of arts/architecture (Sinan).

notes.title: Tanzimat Reforms (1839–76): Modernization & Centralization
notes.content: Key edicts (Gülhane, Hatt-ı Hümāyūn), legal equality, bureaucratic reform; often linked to debates on 'decline' vs. transformation.
keyTakeaways: Aimed at legal rationalization and fiscal-military modernization.
Created new elites and educational institutions.
Set the stage for later constitutionalism.

notes.title: Fall of Constantinople (1453): Methods & Meaning
notes.content: Gunpowder siegecraft, naval blockade, and political ramifications; staple essay for Ottoman ascendancy.
keyTakeaways: Artillery & strategy innovations under Mehmed II.
Shift in trade routes and prestige politics.
Use reliable maps/diagrams for siege narratives.

notes.title: Crusades: Contacts, Conflict & Consequences
notes.content: Beyond battles, exams probe economic/cultural exchanges, military orders, and impacts on both Europe and the Muslim world.
keyTakeaways: Pilgrimage-war nexus and papal authority.
Trade/knowledge flows and military innovations.
Avoid one-sided narratives; present balanced causation.

notes.title: Sufism & the Subcontinent: Spread & Social Embedment
notes.content: Role of Chishtis and other orders in urban/rural networks; exams emphasize method (langar, khānqāh), vernaculars, and inclusive ethics.
keyTakeaways: Trade routes + Sufi lodges = durable conversion networks.
Accommodation of local idioms and social service.
Use case studies (e.g., Delhi/Deccan).

notes.title: Jamāl al-Dīn al-Afghānī & Muḥammad ʿAbduh: Modern Reform
notes.content: Pan-Islamism, ijtihād vs. taqlīd, and educational/juridical reform; often asked to connect to colonial context and later movements.
keyTakeaways: Afghānī's political mobilization and critique of imperialism.
ʿAbduh's legal-theological reform and Al-Azhar influence.
Trace influence on Riḍā and 20th-century reformist currents.

notes.title: Ottoman 'Decline' Debates & Comparative Frames
notes.content: Causes attributed to fiscal strain, military lag, provincial autonomy, and European pressures; avoid 'decline' teleology—use nuanced periodization.
keyTakeaways: Pair administrative reforms with structural constraints.
Consider world-system shifts and technology gaps.
Compare with Safavid/Mughal contemporaries where relevant.

notes.title: Muslim Spain's Transmission to Europe
notes.content: From translation schools (Toledo) to agricultural/technological diffusion; exam favorites: medicine, philosophy, optics, and numerals.
keyTakeaways: Routes of transmission: translation, trade, scholars' travel.
Case names: Ibn Rushd to Aquinas; Ibn al-Haytham's optics.
Argument structure: evidence of influence vs. parallel development.

notes.title: Key MCQs: Geography, Dates & Symbols
notes.content: High-frequency facts: Baghdad on the Tigris; Badr (624 CE); Abbasid black banners; Umayyad capital at Damascus; Qubāʾ as first mosque.
keyTakeaways: Memorize city-river pairs and dynasty capitals.
Associate banners/colors with dynasties (e.g., Abbasid black).
Keep a one-page 'dates & places' crib.

notes.title: Administrative Comparisons: Umayyad vs Abbasid vs Ottoman
notes.content: For long essays, structure around revenue systems, provincial control, law/courts, military, and ideological legitimation.
keyTakeaways: Define metrics first, then compare consistently.
Note continuity (diwan) and innovation (Ottoman kanun).
Use 2–3 concrete policy examples per dynasty.

notes.title: Treaty of Ḥudaybiyyah in Qur'anic Exegesis & Later Politics
notes.content: Pivot to show how 'manifest victory' (al-Fatḥ) frames later reconciliation politics; useful for contemporary analogies in essays.
keyTakeaways: Cite exegetical readings & historical outcomes together.
Use as template for conflict settlement questions.
Ground in specific clauses to avoid generalities.

notes.title: Al-Andalus: Documentary & Lecture Picks (Exam-friendly)
notes.content: Use curated videos for rapid visual recall of timelines, rulers, and monuments; always cross-check with a text source.
keyTakeaways: Pair each video with at least one encyclopedia entry.
Extract 5–7 visual memory hooks (maps/art).
Make a one-page Al-Andalus timeline.

resources.title: AJ — Lessons from the Golden Era of Andalusia

notes.title: Ottoman Military & Legal Synthesis
notes.content: How shari'a (courts, muftis) coexisted with sultanic kanun; exam questions often ask for this duality and its administrative expression.
keyTakeaways: Hierarchies: şeyhülislâm, qadis, provincial judges.
Kanun addressed taxation, land, and criminal matters.
Süleyman's codification as a peak example.

notes.title: CrashCourse & Survey Videos for Rapid Revision
notes.content: Use short videos to refresh big arcs before essays; follow up with reading for citations.
keyTakeaways: Don't quote videos; extract structure and key names/dates.
Build 10-bullet 'storyline' for each era.
Rehearse out loud for timing.

notes.title: Exam Writing Patterns: Compare/Contrast & Causation
notes.content: Common prompts: Treaty of Hudaybiyyah as statecraft; Umayyad vs Abbasid administration; reasons for Umayyad downfall; impact of Crusades; Ottoman decline vs reform.
keyTakeaways: Always define terms & frame a thesis in first paragraph.
Use timelines, maps, and 3–4 evidence clusters per body section.
Close with 'significance' paragraph linking past to present.
